question: Why doesn't it thunder during snow storms?
human_answer: Thunder can occur while it is snowing, sleeting, or even during freezing rain. It is a very rare and unusual occurrence, but thunder snow is known to happen in mid-latitude climates, in the United States. Thunder snow can happen in three different instances. The first example is when a thunderstorm is on the edge of a cold front or a warm front where the precipitation in the atmosphere takes the form of snow. The second instance is when there is a synoptic snowstorm that allows for conditions that cause lightning and thunder to occur. The third one is called the lake effect where a thunderstorm is produced by cold air passing over warmer water, which produces snow squalls that then connect to the thunderstorm. Lake-effect snowstorms have narrow clouds shaped more like ordinary thunderstorms. When the air above the initial cloud layer is relatively cool and dry, and when the added cooling and lifting is strong, a shallow layer just above the original flat cloud can become unstable. This makes it favorable for "elevated convection" – showers or thunderstorms.
webgpt_answer: When there is a snowstorm, the snow dampens the sound of thunder so it sounds like a muffled timpani drum rather than the loud cracking and booming of a summer thunderstorm. Cold winter air typically doesn't contain a lot of moisture and isn't conducive to thunderstorms. Additionally, conditions have to be right for a thunderstorm to form. It requires warm air near the surface of the Earth to rise due to convection. As the hot air rises, cooler air descends to replace it. If conditions are right, strong updrafts can form that quickly move the warm, humid surface air up to the higher reaches of the troposphere, where the water vapor in the air cools and condenses to fall as rain (or ice, if it’s cold enough). These updrafts are a hallmark of thunderstorms. The strong upward motion of the air encourages the interactions between water droplets and ice crystals that can lead to lightning. In winter, cold surface air temperatures and reduced sunlight mean there’s less surface heating, less convection, and thus fewer opportunities for thunderstorms.
gpt3_answer: Thunderstorms typically occur during the summer months when warm, moist air rises and then condenses, creating the perfect environment for lightning and thunder. During a snow storm, the air temperature is much colder and the air is much drier, making the atmosphere less conducive to thunderstorms. When air is colder and drier, it is less likely to rise and form clouds. Without rising air, there is no condensation or lightning, so no thunder. Additionally, snow storms are usually associated with high-pressure systems. Because high-pressure systems have sinking air, this further reduces the likelihood of thunderstorms. Even if there is lightning, the snow usually muffles the sound of the thunder, making it difficult to hear. All in all, snow storms are not ideal environments for thunderstorms, which is why you typically don’t hear thunder during a snow storm.
alpaca_answer: During a snow storm, the air is already full of water particles, which are a good conductor of electricity. When the electric charge builds up, it causes the electrons to flow from one cloud to the other and creates an audible clap of thunder. Since the air is already full of water particles, the electric charge is unable to build up and thus, there is no thunder during snow storms.</s>

 Air instability is also important to thunderstorm formation. It commonly occurs when warm air near the surface of the Earth rises due to convection–in the classic case, on a sunny summer day when the ground gets hot and warms up the air immediately above it. As the hot air rises, cooler air descends to replace it. If conditions are right, strong updrafts can form that quickly move the warm, humid surface air up to the higher reaches of the troposphere, where the water vapor in the air cools and condenses to fall as rain (or ice, if it’s cold enough). These updrafts are a hallmark of thunderstorms–the strong upward motion of the air encourages the interactions between water droplets and ice crystals that can lead to lightning.

 We usually have thundersnow at least a couple of times each winter. Maine is in a kind of unique place, though, in which we can get arctic highs spilling in from Canada and colliding with warmer, wetter air coming up the Eastern seaboard and off the Gulf of Maine.
 
 The most common "cold" thunderstorms are known as elevated thunderstorms. These storms can occur when it is cold at the surface, but there is a warm layer higher up in the atmosphere that provides the energy to the storms.
 
 Ever wonder why these elevated storms seem to have long, drawn-out thunder compared to thunderstorms that occur when it's warm at the surface? With cold air at the surface and warm air above it, the warm air will act as a kind of ceiling, or insulator, to things like sound waves. question: what is visa? (not the credit card)
human_answer: A visa is a document issued by a foreign country you are planning to visit, that allows you to legally enter that country.  Visas are typically issued by immigration authorities, such as a consulate or embassy, and each country has its own visa policy, although generally these processes are similar.  There are many different types of visas, and they are categorized based on the reason for visiting the country, such as tourism visas, student visas, business visas, and medical visas.  The difference between a visa and a passport, is that a passport serves to identify you as a citizen of a country, while a visa allows you to enter a foreign country legally.  Some countries do not require visas, if they have arrangements or agreements with other countries.
webgpt_answer: A visa is an official document that allows the bearer to legally enter a foreign country. It is usually stamped or glued into the bearer's passport. There are several different types of visas, each of which afford the bearer different rights in the host country. A passport is a legal document that is issued to citizens of a country or state, which gives that citizen the potential to travel outside of their home country while enjoying certain rights and protections. A travel visa is another type of legal document that is usually issued by a nation state to a foreign citizen, which may permit the foreigner to enter, stay, work, or travel within the territory. A visa may specify a limit on the length of time the alien may reside in the territory, or set the dates between which they may enter and leave. In the past, visas were usually stamps added to the visitors passport at the border or port of entry, but today, it is much more common to require a visa in advance, before the alien intends to travel.

A single-entry visa allows you to enter the country once, while a multiple-entry visa allows you to enter the country multiple times during the approved period of stay. Depending on the country, a visa may be required for short-term visits, such as for business trips, and for longer-term stays, such as for studying abroad or for permanent residence. Generally, you must apply for a visa from the country’s embassy or consulate in your home country before you travel. When you arrive at your destination, you must present your visa to enter the country. When you leave, you must surrender your visa, unless you are granted an extension. question: Why isn't desalination an easy solution to the upcoming water shortages?
human_answer: Desalination is a process by which highly pressurized sea water is funneled through tiny membrane filters and distilled into drinkable water. Some see this process as a promising solution to global water shortages. The more advanced water treatment plants around the world use Reverse Osmosis for filtration, which is a proven method for portable drinking water. This process is a growing trend and gives hope to countries without rivers and reservoirs. Still there are critics who point out the economic and environmental costs. Desalinating ocean water is the most expensive form of fresh water, given the costs of collecting, distilling and distributing. Desalination can also take a toll on ocean biodiversity. For desalination to be a viable option, renewable energy needs to be used, costs need to be lowered, and environmental protection laws need to be in place for marine life.
webgpt_answer: Desalination is not a simple solution to water shortages, as it is extremely expensive and can have harmful effects on the environment. The infrastructure required to collect, distill, and distribute desalinated water is costly, and the energy requirements are very high. Desalination plants take in salt water straight from the ocean and can kill or harm fish and other small ocean life as water travels from the source to the plant. Additionally, water obtained from desalination costs twice the amount of water from freshwater sources. The only way desalination can be a good option to solving the water crisis is if renewable energy is used, costs are lowered, and environmental protections are put in place for marine life too.
gpt3_answer: Desalination is not an easy solution to the upcoming water shortages due to a number of factors. First and foremost, desalination is a costly process. It requires a large amount of energy to extract salt from seawater and convert it into usable water, and this energy needs to come from somewhere, often from burning fossil fuels. Additionally, the process can be very damaging to the environment. It produces a large amount of brine which can harm marine life, and the chemicals used in desalination can also be damaging to the environment. Finally, the process is not very efficient. It is estimated that only 30-50% of the water produced is actually usable, with the rest being discarded in the form of brine.   Overall, while desalination can be a potential solution to the upcoming water shortages, there are numerous factors that make it an expensive and inefficient option. Investing in better water management and conservation strategies may be a better course of action than relying solely on desalination.

It takes a lot of capital and energy to develop and maintain desalination plants and the technology is still relatively new and untested in some locations. Desalination also requires a lot of energy to process water, and this energy can be costly and hard to come by in some regions. Additionally, it can produce a large amount of waste, which can be costly to dispose of. Finally, desalination can remove minerals and other naturally occurring contaminants from water, which can create issues further down the line.</s>
gpt3_wdoc_answer: Desalination is not an easy solution to the upcoming water shortages because of its high costs and environmental impacts. On the environmental front, desalination can take a toll on ocean biodiversity, as intake pipes to desalination plants take up the larvae of a cross-section of life in the sea, as well as other organisms. Furthermore, the energy requirements for desalination are so high that it is cost-prohibitive for a lot of countries. question: If vegetables are good for us why have we not evolved to like them as much as we like chocolate?
human_answer: Sugar is actually quite healthy when consumed in moderate amounts and in its natural form. The main natural source of sugar is fruit. Now, millions of years later, due to agricultural technology, fruit is a staple food that can be consumed anytime instead of being a rare cache of calories. question: Why is a runners heart rate lower than a non runner
human_answer: Runners have lower resting heart rates because of their training. This is because as they train, their heart increases in size, the muscle walls become thicker, and the heart needs fewer beats to deliver the same about of blood throughout the body than the average person. This can lead to serious problems later on down the road for runners, but for the most part, it's harmless.
webgpt_answer: It is not unusual for healthy people involved in endurance activities to develop a bradycardia, or slow heart rate. This is due to the increased vagal tone from training which suppresses heart rate.  A lower heart rate will deliver the same blood volume in a trained resting heart rate as the higher heart rate in an untrained heart rate.  Endurance athletes and other people who exercise a great deal often have lower-than-average heart rates, sometimes even below 40 beats per minute. This is due to exercise strengthening the heart muscle, enabling it to pump a greater volume of blood with each heartbeat. More oxygen gets delivered to the muscles, so the heart needs to beat fewer times than it would in a less-fit person while at rest.
gpt3_answer: A runner's heart rate is generally lower than that of a non-runner for several reasons. First, regular running helps to strengthen the heart muscle, which increases its efficiency and allows it to pump more blood with each beat. This means that the heart can effectively deliver the same amount of blood to the body with fewer beats, thus lowering the overall heart rate.  Additionally, running can help to improve the body's ability to use oxygen more efficiently, thus reducing the amount of oxygen needed by the heart muscle to contract. This reduces the amount of energy needed to beat and lowers the heart rate.  Finally, running may also cause the body to produce hormones such as adrenaline, which can slow the heart rate. This is because adrenaline acts as a signal to the body to prepare for a physical activity, which causes the heart rate to slow in order to conserve energy.  Overall, the combination of these factors makes the heart rate of a regular runner lower than that of a non-runner. Regular running not only strengthens the heart muscle, but it also improves the body's ability to use oxygen more efficiently and can cause the release of hormones that slow the heart rate.

question: How did people manipulate photographs before computers?
human_answer: Photograph manipulation started shortly after the invention of photography with images captured on glass and tin plates in the late 19th century.  Traditional photographic prints can be altered using various techniques that involve manipulating the print directly with tools such as:  ink, paint, erasers, airbrush, and other art supplies.  Negatives can be manipulated while still in the camera using double-exposure techniques, or in the darkroom by piecing photos or negatives together. Some darkroom manipulations involved techniques such as bleaching to artfully lighten or totally wash-out parts of the photograph, or hand coloring for aesthetic purposes or to mimic a fine art painting.  In early photography color was often added to make the photos more realistic.  This involved manual intervention to enlivening photos with powdered pigment, watercolor and oil paint.
webgpt_answer: The earliest forms of photo manipulation were done in darkrooms. The photographer would combine printing, exposure variations, and alterations to the negative to produce the desired result. Image retouching was done on a special table with a variable inclination angle. The negative was placed on a special frame and shone through from behind using an adjustable mirror or any other reflective surface. There were curtains on top and sides to avoid stray light. Modern image retouching techniques are improving every day, making the lives of many people involved in photography easier. Today, anyone can easily remove or add any element to the photo. Ansel Adams employed some of the more common manipulations using darkroom exposure techniques, burning (darkening) and dodging (lightening) a photograph. Other examples of photo manipulation include retouching photographs using ink or paint, airbrushing, double exposure, piecing photos or negatives together in the darkroom, scratching instant films, or through the use of software-based manipulation tools applied to digital images.
gpt3_answer: Before computers, people manipulated photographs through a variety of methods. Many of these methods involved manually cutting, pasting, and re-photographing images. This was a tedious process that could take hours or even days depending on the complexity of the manipulation. Notable examples of these techniques are photomontage and photo collage. Photomontage was a method of combining multiple images into a single composition. This technique was perfected by the Dadaists and Surrealists in the early 20th century and is still widely used today. Photo collage was a method of combining multiple photographs into a single composition. This was done by cutting out elements from individual images and then arranging them into a new image. This technique was popularized by the Cubists and is still widely used today. Other methods of manipulating photographs before computers included hand tinting, retouching, and solarization. Hand tinting was a method of adding color to black and white photos, usually done by painting over the photograph with dyes, watercolors, or oils. Retouching was a method of removing unwanted elements from a photograph, usually done with a brush or airbrush. Solarization was a technique of partially reversing the tones of a photograph, usually done by exposing the photograph to light during the development process. All of these techniques were used to manipulate photographs before computers, but the process was much more time consuming and labor-intensive than it is today.

question: Why do different European languages have such varying names for Germany?
human_answer: Germany has many different names because it was formed from a cluster of independent regions that had their own languages and dialects. Each Germanic region's name for the land influenced what neighboring countries called Germany in their own languages after it was united. French regions call it Allemagne for the Germanic Alemanni tribe that bordered French lands, and the English once called it a similarly Almain or Alman. Estonia named it Saksamaa for its association with the Saxons, and Finland referred to it as Saksa for the same reason. The Latin "Germania" stemmed from the Roman Empire's influence during its invasion of Europe. Proto-Germanic tribes called the country "nation" or "of the people" in their own dialects, giving rise to Tyskland, Duitsland, and Deutschland from Scandinavia, the Netherlands, and Germany respectively. Niemcy in Polish or Německo in Czech originate from the Proto-Slavic word for "mute". The Baltic names for Germany, like Latvian Vācija and Lithuanian Vokietija, have a more muddled origin but are theorized to come from the Proto-Indo-European word "wek" that means "to speak" or from terms referring to Vikings.
webgpt_answer: Some place names come from the people who inhabit or once inhabited the land. Germany, for example, was Germany to some folks long before the country united and called itself Deutschland. The Romans once named an area of Germany Germania after the first Germanic tribe they heard about. Meanwhile, the French and Spanish named Germany Allemagne and Alemania, respectively, after the Alemanni, which was a southern Germanic tribe. Other place names are the result of the global game of cultural "telephone" that we've been playing for thousands of years. As explorers traipsed around the globe and discovered new places, they often had no idea what to call them, so they asked the locals. The names got passed along on trade routes or through diplomacy, spoken and heard by people who didn't share the same language. Somewhere along the way, a name got garbled or misunderstood or even purposefully changed to accommodate the sounds of one language or another.

During the Middle Ages, the German language was divided into two main branches: High German and Low German. The High German dialects were spoken in the more mountainous regions of the country and were the linguistic precursors to modern Standard German. Meanwhile, the Lower German dialects were spoken in the lowland regions and had a greater influence on the languages of neighboring countries.   The names for Germany in other European languages, such as France and Spain, are derived from the Low German dialects, which were spoken in the lowland regions and had a greater influence on the languages of neighboring countries. For example, the French name for Germany is Allemagne, which derives from the Low German word "alleman" meaning "all people." Similarly, the Spanish name Alemania is derived from the Low German word "allerheiligen," which translates to "all saints."   In addition to the influence of the Low German dialects on the names for Germany in other European languages, other historical events have also contributed to the varying names. For example, the German Empire, which was founded in 1871, was known as "Deutsches Reich" in German and "The Empire of Germany" in English. This name was also adopted by other European countries and is still used today, such as in the Spanish name "Imperio Alemán."   The different names for Germany in European languages are a result of the country's rich cultural and linguistic history. The influence of the Low German dialects, combined with other historical events, has led to a variety of names for Germany across Europe.

question: How can food and drinks that are advertised as 0 calories still be metabolized and used as energy by your body?

question: Why is it harder to fall asleep in noisy environments?
human_answer: The human brain prefers to fall asleep when it feels like it is in a safe environment, what is defined as safe can depend on the person, for example, people who live in cities often won't be disturbed by the noises of traffic but will be distracted by the sounds of animals, this could be the other way around for people in more rural areas. Even people who are used to more noise may perceive quiet noises as threats if its something out of the norm, for example, someone living in a large city used to loud noises could be woken by the sudden and very loud noise of a police siren, or even the sound of a creaking door if it isn't normal. If you are struggling to sleep with loud noises then a white noise machine may help, any large burst of noise will be less of an increase in volume over the background noise, and as such your brain may perceive it as less of a threat.
webgpt_answer:
Noise can disrupt your sleep in several ways. First, it can make it difficult to fall asleep, as noise exposure levels above 55 dBA cause a sleeping person to awaken. Even if the noise doesn't wake you up, it can still cause other disturbances as you sleep. You have more restless body movements, your heart rate goes up, your blood pressure increases, and your breathing changes.

Noise can also cause you to stay awake if you do happen to fall asleep. This is because noise, especially unusual noises, can trigger an automatic "fight or flight" response to noise, which releases energizing stress hormones to prepare you to take emergency action. If this happens repeatedly, over time your stress hormone levels can become chronically elevated, which has a wide range of negative health effects.

If you're trying to sleep in a noisy environment, it's best to try to keep things as quiet as possible. You can try using earplugs, a white noise machine, or keep a radio or television on low volume.

Noise can also disrupt our circadian rhythm, which is the internal clock that controls our sleep-wake cycle. Being exposed to loud, sudden noises can interrupt this cycle and make it harder to stay asleep. Additionally, noise pollution can be stressful and create anxiety, making it harder to feel comfortable enough to fall asleep. With all these factors in play, it's clear that noise can be a major obstacle to getting a good night's rest.

question: The stock exchange part in the movie 'Trading Places'
human_answer:
The feat pulled off by Winthorpe and Valentine in the movie 'Trading Places' was basically a combination of short-selling and strategic use of rigged insider information as opposed to the Duke brothers who were attempting to go long.  A long strategy is the traditional way of making money on the stock markets; buying low and selling high. A short strategy is the reverse, selling high and buying low.
In the movie, the Dukes hired secret agent Mr Beeks to get them the report before anyone else sees it. Unfortunately for them, Winthorpe and Valentine get their hands on the report before the Dukes do and feed them false information. The Dukes are led to believe that the weather was bad, so the harvest was less normal. Therefore the Dukes are expecting high prices (low supply + high demand = high prices). However the actual report signals the opposite - the harvest was unaffected by the bad weather, and the supply will be plentiful. Hence the scope for short-selling, as Winthorpe and Valentine know the price is likely to go down. However, this strategy was profitable for them because their speculation turned out to be correct. If they had been unable to buy the juice they needed, they would have defaulted on their promised deliveries, leaving them owing potentially millions of dollars.
webgpt_answer: In the movie Trading Places, Winthorpe and Valentine short-sold stocks at the New York Stock Exchange. In normal trading, you buy low expecting the price of a security to rise in order to make a profit. When short-selling, you expect the prices to drop instead of rise, so you decide to sell high and buy low. Short-selling implies selling a security you do not own at a high price, with the obligation to buy it back later at a lower price. If the price drops, you made a profit, since the cost of repurchase of the security will be lower than what you got for it during the initial short sale. All those traders who, a minute ago, were buying all they could, now suddenly need to sell. So the price starts falling. When the price hits 29 cents a pound, Winthorpe and Valentine start agreeing to buy orange juice in April. They sold high and bought low. They're rich. The Dukes made the opposite bet and went broke.

question: Why does the President of the United States need to be born in the United States to be eligible to run?
human_answer: One of the main reasons that the framers of the US Constitution included the "natural born" citizenship requirement for the presidency is that they feared foreign influences dictating how the country is run. They were worried that individuals such as wealthy European nobles could use their money and influence to control the Electoral College, and thus take charge of the army and return the country to English rule.  They were also weary of the situation in Europe, where dynasties were constantly vying for power, leading to scenarios  like England's King George I, who was a Hanoverian that did not speak English.
webgpt_answer: The reason that the President of the United States must be born in the United States is actually not because of where they are born, but because of their citizenship.  In order to be eligible to run for President, a person must be a natural born citizen, which means that they were born in the US, or if not, they have at least one parent who is a US citizen.  The reason why the framers of the Constitution wanted this requirement was not just because of potential foreign influence, but also because of the dangers of dynastic succession.  At the time, several European figures - such as France's Marquis de Lafayette, a hero of the Revolutionary War - were quite popular in the New World, so the idea wasn't completely far-fetched.  In addition, the framers learned from the example of Poland, where agents from Russia, Prussia, and Austria conspired to install a friendly monarch, Stanislaus II, and subsequently seized upon his weakness and partitioned the country among themselves.

question: Why does car sickness seem to hit the hardest when you look down at your phone, book, etc.?
human_answer: The brain perceived motion because it receives information from the eyes, ears, and muscles. When these parts send conflicting information, the brain doesn't know which is right and which is wrong, and this is what causes motion sickness. An example of this is when reading a book while you are in a moving car. To your eyes, the book is stationary while your inner ear and the rest of your body can feel a sense of motion. This would likely cause car sickness.
webgpt_answer: Motion sickness is usually caused when your inner ear and your eyes disagree about whether you’re moving. When you read in a car, your visual field stays still but your inner ear detects the twists and turns. This sensory conflict triggers nausea, possibly because the brain thinks you’ve eaten something toxic that’s making you hallucinate. It is also common to get motion sickness from staring at your phone or iPad or any other screen during a bumpy ride.
gpt3_answer: Car sickness, also known as motion sickness, is a common issue that can be caused by a variety of factors, including reading, looking at a phone or other device, or even just by observing the motion of the car. When we read or look down at our phones or other devices, we can become disoriented and lose track of the car's movement. This disconnect between our eyes and our sense of motion can confuse our brains and upset our inner ears, which are responsible for helping us maintain balance and orientation. This, in turn, can cause us to become nauseous, dizzy, and experience other uncomfortable symptoms. Additionally, when we look down at our phones, we don't take in the visual cues that can help us keep our sense of balance and orientation, such as the movement of trees and other objects outside the car. By avoiding these distractions and keeping our eyes on the road, we can help reduce the likelihood of experiencing car sickness. Taking breaks from reading or looking at our phones can also help, as this can help us to reset and reorient ourselves back to our environment.

Additionally, focusing on a certain object for a long period of time can lead to motion sickness due to the lack of environmental stimuli. Finally, the act of reading or looking at a phone can take your mind off of the motion of the vehicle, which can worsen the feeling of car sickness.</s>

question: Why does sound get tinny when slowed down?
human_answer: Scrolled down
webgpt_answer:
The pitch of a sound is entirely determined by how far apart in time the peaks are in the soundwave. When you play a sound faster, the peaks become closer together and the pitch goes up. When you play a sound slower, they're further apart, and the pitch goes down. And that's true whether you do it digitally or with analogue tapes or with vinyl.

The simplest way to change the duration or pitch of an audio recording is to change the playback speed. Unfortunately, the frequencies in the recording are always scaled at the same ratio as the speed, transposing its perceived pitch up or down in the process. Thus the two effects cannot be separated when using this method. A drum track containing no pitched instruments can be moderately sample-rate converted to adjust tempo without adverse effects, but a pitched track cannot.
gpt3_answer: When sound is slowed down, it can start to sound tinny because the frequencies of the sound are affected. As the speed of the soundwave is decreased, the frequency of the wave is also decreased. This means that the soundwave is no longer composed of the same frequencies and can start to sound different. The decrease in frequency can cause the sound to become more distorted and tinny. Additionally, as the speed of the soundwave decreases, the sound wave becomes more compressed and can sound less full. This also contributes to the tinny sound.
alpaca_answer: When sound is slowed down, the frequency of the sound waves is altered, resulting in a lower sound pressure level. This change causes the sound to become tinny because the lower sound pressure level is not loud enough to reproduce the full sound that was present at the original speed.</s>
gpt3_wdoc_answer: When you slow down a sound, the peaks of the soundwave become further apart and the pitch goes down. This creates what is called the 'Chipmunk effect', where the sound becomes high-pitched and tinny. This is because when you slow down the sound, the frequencies in the recording are always scaled at the same ratio as the speed, transposing its perceived pitch up in the process. Thus, the effect of slowing down the sound is that the pitch increases and the sound becomes tinny. This effect is difficult to avoid when using sample rate conversion to change the duration or pitch of an audio recording, as the two effects cannot be separated.
alpaca_wdoc_answer: When a sound is slowed down, its pitch is decreased, which causes its frequency range to become lower in pitch, or "tinny." This is because the waveform of a sound wave is a representation of the amplitude of the sound pressure at different points in time, and when the waveform is made up of fewer peaks, or sounds, the overall sound is lower in frequency. In other words, when a song is slowed down, its tempo is decreased, and the sound waves are stretched out, thus decreasing the number of peaks and creating a lower frequency. Similarly, when a song is sped up, its tempo is increased and more peaks are heard, creating a higher frequency.</s>
gpt3_wranddoc_answer: When sound is slowed down, it becomes tinny because the sound waves become more compressed, resulting in a decrease in the number of frequencies. This causes the sound to become less full and more “tinny”. The reason this happens is because when sound waves become more compressed, the overall sound wave is shorter and the time it takes for the sound wave to complete one cycle is quicker. This means that the frequency of the sound wave is higher, resulting in a decrease in the number of frequencies the human ear can detect. This is why slower sound waves sound more tinny than faster sound waves. Additionally, as sound waves become more compressed, the amplitude of the sound waves decrease, resulting in a lower volume and a less full sound. In some cases, the decrease in amplitude can be so extreme that the sound waves become inaudible, resulting in complete silence.
alpaca_wranddoc_answer: When sound is slowed down, its frequency range is compressed. This means that the sound becomes more intense, which can make it louder and sharper. This can produce a tinny sound. Slowing down sound also changes the pitch, which can make it sound higher or lower. The tinny sound is usually due to a change in pitch.</s>
gpt3_wbingdoc_answer: The tinny sound you hear when you slow down audio is a result of the audio signal being overly compressed. This compression can cause a loss of low frequencies, resulting in a sound that is thin and tinny. The compression can be caused by a number of different things, including the software you are using, the settings you have chosen for your audio, or the hardware you are using. If you are using a software to slow down the audio, make sure it is set to preserve the low frequencies so that the sound does not get distorted. If you are using hardware such as a microphone or audio interface, make sure it is properly configured and that you are using the correct settings. Lastly, make sure that the audio is not being over-processed, as this can also lead to a tinny sound.
alpaca_wbingdoc_answer: When sound is slowed down, the frequency range is altered to some extent. This causes certain frequencies that have a higher amplitude when heard with the normal speed to become slightly weaker. Additionally, the rate of vibrations of the speakers are increased and the amplifiers need to work harder to keep up, resulting in distortion and a tinny sound.</s>
gpt3_whudoc_answer: When a sound is slowed down, the frequency of the sound waves is decreased. This decrease in frequency leads to a decrease in the wavelength of the sound waves, which then leads to a decrease in the perceived pitch. As the pitch decreases, the sound becomes higher, more tinny, and less full. This is sometimes referred to as the "Chipmunk effect" because it can make the sound resemble the high-pitched voice of a cartoon chipmunk. The effect is more noticeable when slowing down audio recordings with pitched instruments and can not be separated from changing the length of the recording when using sample-rate conversion.
alpaca_whudoc_answer: When sound is played slower, the peaks in the waveform become further apart, lowering the amplitude and resulting in a tinny sound. This is because the waveform of a slowed-down sound is less intense than the original, and it becomes more difficult for the speaker to reproduce the sound. The result is a sound which is weaker and less pronounced.</s>

question: Why do french fries taste awful if reheated, but something like pizza is comparable whether fresh or reheated?
human_answer: Leftover French fries taste weird when they’re reheated because they are more dehydrated. The starches in the fries secrete moisture, which goes to the fries’ crust, making them soggy and limp. Uncooked rice contains bacterium called Bacillus Cereus, and unfortunately they can survive cooking. This bacterium can germinate, producing toxins which cause food poisoning. These will remain on the rice, even if you reheat them.
webgpt_answer: There are several reasons why reheated food tends to taste bad. One reason is that the composition and structure of the food is damaged by the microwave. The cell structure of the food gets ruptured and it totally changes the taste of your food. Another reason is that the temperature of the food is changed. The heat can heighten the flavors in foods, but it can also cause the oils in french fries to become rancid. A third reason is that the food may have been fried in a cheap oil like vegetable oil, which has a low boiling point. When the food is reheated, the oils tend to cook the fries while the water inside the fries evaporates.

When they are first cooked, the high temperature of the oil seals the outside of the fries and locks in the moisture inside. However, when they are reheated, the outside of the fries begins to dry out and the moisture inside escapes, leaving them dry and unpleasant to eat.  In comparison, pizza is a dish that can be reheated relatively easily. This is because pizza is usually made with a doughy crust and a variety of toppings that are generally low in moisture. As the pizza is reheated, the dough begins to crisp and the toppings heat up, releasing their flavors. This creates a texture and flavor similar to when the pizza was freshly made. Additionally, the toppings also help to keep the crust from drying out, which helps to keep it from becoming too hard or crunchy.   Overall, the differences in the components of french fries and pizza are the reason why french fries tend to taste awful when reheated, while pizza can still taste good after being reheated.

Reheating pizza, on the other hand, generally involves lower temperatures to warm it up, which does not cause the same reaction and does not produce free radicals.</s>

question: if I need pain relief, how do I know whether to choose between aspirin, Tylenol, Advil, etc.? They are all labeled as pain relievers.
human_answer: There are differences between the most common OTC pain relievers. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is best used for headaches, arthritis pain, and fevers. It's also less likely to cause stomach issues. Ibuprofen (Advil) is best used for menstrual cramps, headaches, toothaches, backaches, arthritis, muscle strains, and gout. This is because ibuprofen helps to reduce inflammation and lower prostaglandins which are hormone-like substances that cause you to feel pain. Naproxen is similar to ibuprofen in the sense that it helps to reduce inflammation. It is best used for menstrual cramps, backaches, toothaches, colds, headaches, and arthritis. Finally, Aspirin is one of the oldest pain relievers. It works by doing similar things like ibuprofen and naproxen as it is also an NSAID. It is best used for headaches, toothaches, colds, and fevers.
webgpt_answer: Aspirin, ibuprofen, and naproxen are NSAIDs (Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) that reduce pain, swelling, and fever by inhibiting the body's COX enzymes. Acetaminophen is an analgesic (pain reliever/fever reducer) that works in the heat center of the brain to reduce fever and also affects serotonin pathways in the central nervous system to reduce pain. Ibuprofen is similar to acetaminophen in that it is also an analgesic, but it also has the added effect of acting as an anti-inflammatory medication. Therefore, ibuprofen is typically more effective when inflammation is involved, such as with sprains and strains. Because acetaminophen is metabolized by the liver and ibuprofen is metabolized by the kidneys, they are not great options for those with liver or kidney issues. However, for those who do not have any issues, it is sometimes recommended to alternate between the two to avoid overdosing on painkillers.

The best thing to do is to read the labels and look for the active ingredients. Aspirin, Tylenol, and Advil all contain different active ingredients, so it is important to understand how each one works in order to make an informed decision.   Aspirin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that works to reduce inflammation and pain. Aspirin works quickly and is often recommended for pain relief caused by inflammation. It can also help reduce fever and can be used as a blood thinner to help prevent heart attack and stroke. However, aspirin can also cause stomach upset and may interact with other medications, so it is important to talk to your doctor before taking it.   Tylenol is an acetaminophen-based drug that works to reduce pain and fever. It does not reduce inflammation, but it can be effective in providing relief from mild to moderate pain. It is also relatively safe, with few side effects. However, it can cause liver damage if taken in large doses or combined with certain other medications, so it is important to talk to your doctor before taking it.   Advil is an ibuprofen-based drug that is an NSAID like aspirin. It works to reduce inflammation and pain, and can also reduce fever. It is generally considered safe and effective, but can cause stomach upset and can interact with other medications, so it is important to talk to your doctor before taking it.   Ultimately, it is important to read the labels and understand the active ingredients in order to make an informed decision about which pain reliever is right for you. Talk to your doctor if you have any questions or concerns about taking any of these medications.

question: Why are there only circular planets? Why can't there be square or rectangular ones?
human_answer: This is because of the way planets form. As the pieces bump into each other, they form clumps and these clumps grow big enough to develop gravitational fields. As the gravitational fields grow stronger more and more debris is gathered and soon the collisions cause the clump to become a hot molten core. Additionally, as the planet is rotating at a high speed, gravity is trying to flatten the planet from all points and the most stable shape is spherical. This process is called isotactic adjustment.
webgpt_answer: All planets are round because when they formed, they were made up of molten material that acted like a very hot liquid. Since gravity always points toward the center of a mass, it squeezed the stuff that planets are made of equally in all directions, and this caused the planets to form a ball. As these planets cooled down, they remained in their spherical shape because this is the shape that the gravity of the planet pulled them into. However, these planets are not perfect spheres. They have bulges in their round shapes from the spin of the planet, and these bulges get bigger the faster the planet spins. Additionally, objects can impact planets, creating craters and bumps on their surfaces. For comparison, you can look at asteroids. Smaller asteroids are generally not round because they have very weak gravitational pulls, and therefore cannot pull all the material surrounding them towards their center equally.

question: Why do we have a finite amount of teeth?
human_answer: Baby teeth that fall out are replaced by adult teeth because humans are born with two sets of teeth. The first set develops in the womb and shape the jaw, teach proper chewing, and help with speech development. They are replaced by the second set of adult teeth as the jaw grows and develops. Humans do not have the ability that some animals do to repeatedly grow new sets of teeth due to evolutionary differences. Stem cells, which morph into necessary cells such as ones to grow new teeth, are responsible for the ability of animals like geckos to regrow teeth over and over. Humans have stem cells in their gums as children, but the stem cells die after the adult teeth have grown, preventing more sets of teeth from growing. The evolutionary reason for this could be that mammals like humans had specific diets that required specific tooth shapes and alignments. Growing new sets of adult teeth repeatedly came with the risk of every new tooth being misshapen or out of alignment, so having only one set of properly-aligned adult teeth led to better chances of survival.

Adult teeth can be lost if they are not cared for or if trauma damages them severely enough. The reason we have baby teeth is because we are diphyodonts, meaning we grow two sets of teeth. Our first set of teeth, our baby teeth, come in while our skulls are still small and developing because our jaws aren't large enough to accommodate the number and size of adult teeth we'll eventually have.

Our baby teeth serve as placeholders until our adult teeth are ready to come in. Once our adult teeth have grown in, the stem cells in our gums that help build new teeth die and disappear. While some mammals can regrow teeth multiple times, humans can only grow two sets.

question: What is the "natural" sleeping position for humans.
human_answer:
The best position to sleep in is partially dependent on both your age and any health conditions you may have. 

The most popular sleeping position is side-sleeping. Sleeping on your side may reduce snoring and lower back pain. However, if you sleep in a tight fetal position, you may experience morning soreness. 

Sleeping on your back is great for the spine, as gravity will help create an even alignment across your back. However, sleeping on your back can also worsen respiratory conditions like sleep apnea.

Sleeping on your stomach is perhaps the worst position for your spine, although sleeping with a flat (or no) pillow may reduce the strain on your back. Sleeping on the stomach is also a dangerous position for infants.

This is supported by a study showing that children sleep on the side, back, and front equally, with a growing preference for the side position when approaching adulthood. Side-sleeping with an arm overhead is the most common sleep position, representing 55 percent of the time asleep in bed. Research suggests that the preferred side position increases with age due to a loss of flexibility of the spine. The "natural" position is to sleep on your side, with knees bent and arms folded. This position allows the natural curvature of the spine.

question: Why is automatic transmission fluid so unique? Does the viscosity of ATF change the more it moves?
human_answer: Without transmission fluid to lubricate the variety of cogs, gears, and bearings in your gearbox, your vehicle would suffer from an excessive amount of wear and tear and you would need to replace those parts frequently. Automatic transmission fluid is very different from manual, which is designed to be pressurized so it can activate the clutches and internal parts that change your gears automatically. Typically, it's synthesized to work under high pressure and temperature situations, and is far less likely to break down or oxidize. Automatic transmissions (wet clutches) require hydrodynamic clutches, torque converters, and wet brakes that always require low-viscosity, mildly additivated gear lubrication with high oxidation stability. Even though automatic transmission fluid is quite sophisticated, an element of wear and tear in your gearbox is inevitable. Tiny specks of metal will eventually grind away and float within the fluid, building up over time and affecting the consistency of the fluid despite filters within the system. When this happens, the automatic transmission fluid will be less capable of protecting those internal parts and your vehicle's performance may be adversely affected, so you should take your vehicle in for automatic transmission service at predetermined intervals.
webgpt_answer:
Automatic transmission fluid, or ATF, is hydraulic fluid designed to pressurize clutches in automatic transmissions to engage the correct gears. The fluid's friction properties determine whether the complicated choreography of moving metal and fluid creates crisp shifts or has you scheduling a time to change transmission fluid.  

Automatic transmissions use pressurized ATF to change gears. When your vehicle’s computer decides it’s time to shift gears, it sends an electric signal to the appropriate transmission solenoid. The solenoid directs fluid through a complex series of passages in the valve body to engage the correct gear. The fluid squeezes a series of plates together inside a clutch pack to connect the engine to the transmission output shaft and route power to the wheels.


In a properly functioning transmission, this all happens instantly and goes largely unnoticed. However, fluid that’s too thick (its viscosity is too high) can fail to flow quickly for crisp, confident shifts. That’s one reason automatic transmission fluid has a lower viscosity than manual transmission fluid.
gpt3_answer: Automatic transmission fluid (ATF) is a unique type of lubricant specifically designed to help maintain the proper functioning of a vehicle's automatic transmission system. ATF is unique because it is designed to meet the specific needs and requirements of an automatic transmission system, which can differ from the needs of other vehicle systems.  ATF is a type of lubricant that consists of a combination of base oil and detergents, dispersants, additives, and viscosity modifiers. The viscosity of ATF is designed to remain constant, even over time and with the normal wear and tear of an automatic transmission system. This is because the viscosity modifiers in ATF help to keep the lubricant at the same thickness or viscosity, even as the transmission system ages and wears over time. This helps keep the transmission system running smoothly and prevents excessive wear and tear on the system's components. In other words, the viscosity of ATF does not change as the fluid moves throughout the transmission system.
alpaca_answer: Automatic transmission fluid, or ATF, is a special type of liquid designed to provide the best performance from automatic transmissions. ATF is different from regular engine oil because it has special additives that allow it to provide a smooth and efficient shift action. Additionally, the viscosity of ATF is designed to be at its highest when the transmission is at its hottest, allowing for more effective cooling. As the fluid moves through the torque converter, the viscosity is slowly reduced until it reaches its optimal level, providing quicker shifts and more efficient performance.</s>

The fluid must have the right viscosity to flow quickly for crisp shifts, which is why automatic transmission fluid has a lower viscosity than manual transmission fluid. The viscosity of ATF does not change the more it moves, but it is formulated with long-chain hydrocarbons that have a polar group on one end, which provides the desired amount of friction. The various types of ATF differ in the fluid’s friction characteristics.

question: How do ads follow me from my phone to my computer?
human_answer: Advertising agencies usually use cookies stored on your device to track what types of information you have looked at. The agencies use that information to determine the kind of products and services you may be interested in and they give you ads based on those predictions. This can be done on different devices because logging into google confirms which other devices you use. Sometimes this can be the case even without logging into any accounts because Facebook and Google collect metadata from some sites and can even use your phone contacts to make suggestions or guess the products you may be interested in.
webgpt_answer: When you visit a website, the site may or may not show ads, but they do include content from an advertising network. The advertising network places a cookie on your computer. That cookie contains information to the effect of, “This computer was looking at X,” where X is the product or service offered by the site you’re visiting. You move on to another website — a site that also displays ads, and coincidentally uses the same advertising network as the site you started at. That advertising network is given its own cookie back — the one that says, “This computer was looking at X” — and as a result, elects to show you ads for X. Technically, this type of tracking isn’t tracking you as an individual; it’s just a side effect of the places your computer has visited. Any computer that happens to view product X will likely see ads for X as they visit other sites.
gpt3_answer: Ads that follow you from your phone to your computer are known as "cross-device tracking" or "multi-device tracking." This type of tracking works by collecting data about you and your device, such as your IP address, device type, and browser, and then using that data to track your activity across all of your devices. For example, if you visit a website on your phone, the company may track the same website on your computer, or they may track different websites that they think you may be interested in. This data is then used to target you with ads that are tailored to your interests.  Cross-device tracking is becoming increasingly prevalent, and it is enabled by a variety of different technologies. Companies often use cookies and other tracking technologies to track your activity across multiple devices. They may also use a device graph, which is an algorithm that links devices together based on their similarities. This technology can even be used to figure out which devices belong to the same person, so the company can track their activity across all of the devices that they own.  In addition, many companies are now using advanced machine learning techniques to track user behavior across multiple devices. For example, a company may use a machine learning algorithm to identify patterns in your activity, such as which websites you visit or which apps you use, and then use that data to target you with ads.  Overall, cross-device tracking is becoming an increasingly common practice, and it can be a powerful tool for companies to target ads to users. However, it is important to be aware of this practice, as it can be intrusive and potentially invade your privacy.
alpaca_answer: Ad tracking is mostly done through cookies, which are small text files placed on the device by the websites you visit. The cookies track your device’s unique ID, which can then be used to follow your online activity across different websites. Additionally, ad tracking algorithms are also used to track users by recognizing patterns in their browsing behavior, such as the websites they visit and the content they view. This data is then used to target ads that are tailored to the user’s interests.</s>

question: Why are so many people choosing longboards over traditional skateboards these days? Are they easier to ride? What is the benefit?
human_answer: Longboards are longer and wider than skateboards. Longboards have large soft wheels and skateboards have small, hard wheels. Longboards are more flexible and easier to ride for beginners. You’ll also see how flat the nose and tail of the longboard are, whereas there’s more of a curve on the nose and tail of the skateboards. The big soft wheels on the longboards are great for riding, and rolling over cracks at high speeds, but are more bouncy compared to hard wheels. You don’t want to use soft wheels to perform tricks because the board can bounce back. Skateboards have small trucks, while longboards have wider trucks with a different design. Wide trucks give you more stability which is needed at high speeds, and smaller trucks make the board more agile, which is needed for flips.

question: Why do Women typically play softball rather than baseball in the U.S.?
human_answer: In the U.S., women mostly play softball rather than baseball because of historical restrictions dating back decades.  While women used to play baseball during World War II, they were eventually discouraged from doing so around the 1950's.  During the women's liberation movement, and the Title IX law was passed that required equal funding to both male and female sports teams, baseball was not one of the sports that saw significant change. The reason for this is that the law dictated that schools must provide equivalent sports, and softball is considered equivalent to baseball.  Because of this, women's baseball is not a high school or collegiate sport in the United States, and girls must play on boys teams, leading to often overwhelming pressure.

There are Title IX regulations in place that state that men's and women's college sports teams should receive equal funding. Title IX also says that for male-only sports, there can be an equivalent for women and vice versa. Since softball is the only female-only sport that qualifies, it is associated more with women.

Softball uses a 12-inch ball instead of a 9-inch one, like what you'd see in baseball. The more massive size of the softball was developed to create a body that won't travel as far, making it more useful for the smaller softball field size. The design is also more accessible for women to handle, as it doesn't require them to travel too far to reach a batted ball.

Women stuck with softball because they didn't have any significant baseball leagues for play. While there was a prominent American women's baseball league in the 1940s, it became less popular when American male players returned from the war in the 1950s.  Thus, women will play softball instead because they know there's a good structure for development in that sport.

question: Why does 'quick sand' make you sink and where does the sand go?
human_answer:
Quicksand is created when fine sediment becomes soaked with water. Although the surface can appear solid and dry, once weight is put on, the sand or other substance (clay, silt, soil) will be pressed down. This will cause it to mix with the water underneath, forming a thickened slurry.

As a person or object sinks into the quicksand, it becomes displaced. Because the quicksand's density is double that of humans, the sand will only displace to the point where both the person and quicksand become equal. This results in floating, usually around chest/waist level for a person. But as the weight of the person or other object displaces the sand, becoming equal, the mixing of water ceases and the sediment will reform into a more solid material.

When someone steps onto the quicksand, the mixture is jiggled. Then it flows like a liquid, and the sand starts sinking to the bottom. The more the person struggles, the more watery the quicksand becomes. A person won’t sink under, at most about halfway. Still, quicksand is dangerous because the thick sand below may trap a person far away from help.  Quicksand is basically just ordinary sand that has been so saturated with water that the friction between sand particles is reduced. The resulting sand is a mushy mixture of sand and water that can no longer support any weight. It is rarely deeper than a few feet. If you step into quicksand, it won’t suck you down. However, your movements will cause you to dig yourself deeper into it.

question: can weather or storms actually be controlled or man made? If so, to what extent and how?
human_answer:
Scientists have found a method to control the weather in a lab setting, called cloud seeding.  The principle is based on an airplane flying into the clouds, and releasing a cloud of silver iodide to produce rain in a drought area. Lab experiments seem to indicate that cloud seeding barely worked, if at all. Still, Chinese scientists believe they have successfully controlled cloud seeding so they can manipulate which day will be rainy or sunny. 

In the world of weather warfare, the US air-force has referenced using controlled lighting strikes to attack its targets. The suggestion is that weather controlling is possible with electromagnetic waves. The US military has created a large weapons platform called High Frequency Active Auroral Research Project (HAARP) to do more research on man-made weather controlling.

Experiments have been conducted on cloud seeding to create rainfall artificially. This method uses chemicals to induce nucleation and promote rainfall. China claimed that it made snowfall in Beijing on Sunday February 5th, the earliest and heaviest snowfall there in years. This information can be used to create early warning systems and evacuation plans as well as to assist in disaster relief efforts.   Overall, while it is not possible to completely control the weather or storms, there are ways to manipulate and manage certain aspects of it to some degree. question: If you put water bottles under a frozen lake when the outside temperate is below freezing will the bottles not freeze because the water under a lake is still liquid
human_answer: All water freezes at 32 degrees Fahrenheit. But when lakes freeze and a layer of ice forms on the surface, it will act sort of as insulation and retain heat. As winter approaches, lakes lose energy to the atmosphere and the water near the surface cools, becomes more dense, and sinks. Warmer, less dense water under the surface will rise to replace this surface water. Once the surface water falls to 32 F, it freezes, and the freezing then spreads downward into the lake and the ice thickens. It is possible for water bottles to stay unfrozen under a frozen lake if the water is shallow enough.

question: Why is it cheaper for employers to have their workers get compensatory time instead of overtime pay?
human_answer: Employers are legally bound by the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) to give employees certain benefits. In some cases, employees may be able to choose whether they get overtime or comp time pay. Giving employees a choice may benefit the company in the sense that employees may feel more satisfied in their workplace environment. In other cases, FLSA exempt employees may be required to take comp time pay instead of overtime pay.
webgpt_answer: Compensatory time is far cheaper for employers than paying overtime.  The employer would have to pay the employee $135 (overtime rate of $15/hr x 9 hours = $135) if the overtime were paid as overtime. However, if the employer “allows” the employee to bank those hours, the employer only pays the employee $90 (regular rate of $10/hr. x 9 hours = $90). The savings can really add up for the employer.  In addition, weekly scheduling benefits the employer as they would not have to pay the overtime premium. The upside for the employees is it gives them access to short periods of time off each week that they might need to attend to personal matters or simply spend more time with their families.
gpt3_answer: Compensatory time, also known as “comp time,” is an alternative to paying overtime wages, which is often cheaper for employers. It allows employers to provide employees with time off in lieu of overtime wages. This means that instead of paying an employee for the extra hours worked, the employer provides the employee with extra time off. This is beneficial to employers because they can save money by not having to pay overtime wages. It is also beneficial to employees because they can receive extra time off instead of extra wages, allowing them to use their time in whatever way they choose. Additionally, comp time can help employers save on payroll taxes, since they don’t have to pay the additional taxes associated with overtime wages. Comp time is also beneficial to employers because it can help them manage their labor costs more effectively and reduce the risk of overtime liability. For example, if an employer provides comp time to an employee instead of paying overtime wages, they won’t have to worry about overtime liability since the employee won’t be working extra hours. Comp time also provides employers with greater flexibility when it comes to scheduling, since they can choose when to give their employees the compensatory time off. This can be especially helpful during peak periods when demand is high and they need to schedule employees to work extra hours. Overall, compensatory time is often a cheaper and more flexible alternative to paying overtime wages and can help employers save money and manage their labor costs more effectively.
alpaca_answer: It is cheaper for employers to provide compensatory time instead of overtime pay because it allows them to give employees extra time off in lieu of paying them for additional hours worked. This can be beneficial for employers because it allows them to control labor costs while still allowing employees to work additional hours if needed. By providing compensatory time, employers also don't have to worry about paying overtime rates, which can be significantly higher than regular rates. In addition, providing compensatory time can help employers avoid the stress that can come with dealing with overtime requests and managing staffing levels to make sure there is enough coverage.</s>
gpt3_wdoc_answer: Employers prefer to offer compensatory time, or “comp time”, to their hourly workers instead of overtime pay because it is far more cost-effective. When an employee works overtime, the employer is required to pay the employee a premium rate for those hours that are over their regular hours. For example, if an employee works nine hours of overtime and their regular hourly rate is $10, the employer would have to pay the employee $135 (overtime rate of $15/hr x 9 hours = $135). However, if the employer allows the employee to bank those hours, they only have to pay the employee $90 (regular rate of $10/hr. x 9 hours = $90). This means the employer is only paying the employee the regular rate, without having to pay the overtime premium.   California Labor Code § 204.3 allows employers to offer comp time instead of overtime pay, as long as the employer and employee agree in writing, the employee requested in writing to receive comp time, the employee is regularly scheduled to work at least 40 hours per week, and the comp time is paid at the equivalent overtime rate the employee would earn. Comp time gives the employee access to short periods of time off each week that they might need to attend to personal matters or simply spend more time with their families, while saving the employer money in the process.
alpaca_wdoc_answer:
Compensatory time is cheaper for employers than overtime pay because the employer does not have to pay the overtime premium. For example, if an employee typically earns $10 per hour and works 9 hours of overtime, the employer would have to pay the employee $90. question: Why does HTTPS/SSL need a certificate to do secure transmission, while SSH does not?
human_answer:
HTTPS and SSL exist to ensure your website is trustworthy. Because your webpage is certificated, your customers know they are protected when browsing or purchasing from your website. HTTPS stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure, a secure version of HTTP, which means communication between your customer and your website is secure and encrypted. This is beneficial when your customers enter credit card information and other personal information to buy your products or services online. SSL, which stands for Secure Socket Layer, is the encryption communication that your HTTPS website uses to encrypt your customer’s sensitive information. 

SSL is based on certificates, while SSH is based on network tunneling. SSL is used to encrypt communication between browser and serve, and SSH encrypts communication between two computers over the internet. In SSL, communication is authenticated using a private-key/public-key pair, whereas SSH uses username/password pair. SSL is used to securely send sensitive information like credit cards and banking, and SSH is used to securely perform commands over the internet.

question: Why is eating burnt food bad for you?
human_answer: When certain foods are cooked at high temperatures, sugars, such as glucose and fructose, can react with the free amino acid, asparagine, to form acrylamide. Acrylamide caused cancer in animals in studies where animals were exposed to acrylamide at very high doses. In 2010, the Joint Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) concluded that acrylamide is a human health concern and suggested additional long-term studies. When it comes to cooking meat, there are two different chemicals that occur when meat is cooked. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are formed when fat and juices drip onto flames while frying, baking, or grilling meat. Heterocyclic amines (HCAs) form when meat is exposed to high temperatures for a prolonged period; the longer the exposure, the more HCAs are formed.  Seventeen different HCAs resulting from the cooking of muscle meats have been identified, which may pose human cancer risk. HCAs develop a powerful carcinogenic potential when activated by cytochrome P450 1A2-mediated oxidation of the amino group, which is followed by acetylation or sulfation to form direct-acting reactive mutagens that attack key elements in DNA. When fed to rats, several of these HCAs can induce cancer of the mammary glands, colon, and pancreas.

question: Explain: (to Americans): Canadian Election today
human_answer:
The Canadian government is divided into national, provincial, and local levels. Members of the House of Commons are selected in the national election; members of the Senate are not elected. Canadians can vote for leaders in the 10 provincial parliaments. Voting is conducted at the poll or via absentee ballots.

Those who are running for elected positions typically campaign before an election. A party that wins with 169 or fewer seats forms a minority government and will have to work with other political parties to get anything done.

question: Who starts chain letters ("Pass this on or you'll die within the next seven months" or "Send this to ten people within the next seven hours and you'll receive good luck for the next year") and how do they benefit from them? Who profits?
human_answer: Chain letters are letters sent via the postal service or by e-mail that direct the recipient to send out multiple copies so that circulation increases. They may tell a joke, promise good fortune, threaten you with bad luck, or inform you of another's tragedy or misfortune, and often make promises to the recipient in exchange for sending the message to other people. Some people send chain letters to obtain new email addresses that may lead to new contacts. Each time the letter is sent to someone new, their address will be added to the list of recipients and the original senders will have obtained the addresses they wanted while exerting little effort. People also send chain letters to see how far they will go or to harass another person. And some people are out to get money, and may be successful, through pyramid schemes distributed through an e-mail chain.

question: How do our minds estimate the passage of time?
human_answer: Studies involving the brain's perception of time passage have shown a few things. One suggests the way we perceive time depends on changes in what we see. When the speed of what we see changes, our perception of time will change accordingly. Another study shows the brain reacts to time passing more quickly if we are busy or enjoying something. On the contrary, when bored, the brain will decipher this as time passing more slowly. It is believed we have two different systems for processing time, one for circadian rhythm and another for time passage awareness.

question: Why was the USS Enterprise CVN-65 decommissioned?
human_answer: The U.S.S. Enterprise CVN-65 was the third oldest commissioned vessel in the US Navy before being decommissioned and dismantled.  It was also the longest naval vessel ever built, making it impractical to store. Its eight nuclear reactors needed to be removed, making it too expensive to turn into a museum piece. Since the Enterprise was also the only member of its ship class, it has no other peers currently in service.

question: why does the file size of digital photos vary when the pixel count doesn't change?
human_answer: While pixel count has a large effect on the file size, several factors can make equal pixel counts create files of different sizes. If an image file is saved using compression, the compression process encodes the file more efficiently, decreasing the amount of detail in the saved image and thus decreasing its file size. The file is smaller the more compressed the image is, but the original pixel count is still recorded for when the file is reopened. The depth of color also affects the file size. Pixels can have a color depth of 8, 16, or 24 bits per pixel, with higher bit counts corresponding to more colors that each pixel can display. Different color depths also change the file size due to different bit counts, even though the pixel count may be the same.

question: Why am I unstable on my bike when it's stationary but not when it's moving?
human_answer:
When a bicycle is stationary, there are only two points of support between the bicycle and the ground with the base of support being a line segment. But in order for an object to have a stable base of support, three contact points with the ground are necessary. 

When a bicycle is moving, those two points of support, the part of each wheel touching the ground, are now being expanded because the wheels are in movement with steering allowing those points of support to be moved around to adjust to the center of gravity, therefore balancing the bike. The spinning wheels also play a part in the balance. When the spinning wheels line up in a specific manner, they want to remain in that position. Although you can alter their alignment, outside forces cannot easily do the same.

question: Why is it that a fully buffered YouTube video will buffer again from where you click on the progress bar when you skip a few seconds ahead?
human_answer: When YouTube buffers a video, both your computer and the YouTube server have to load the video data. If the YouTube server is overloaded with users, the server may be unable to transfer data fast enough to maintain the buffer constantly. Skipping ahead can cause a hiccup in the connection because the YouTube server cannot stream the data to your computer fast enough. When this happens, rather than the server providing a constant, smooth buffer, it has to refresh the buffer to reload the data. This can also happen when your internet connection cannot handle the amount of data being streamed from the server all at once, so it buffers but has to reload repeatedly to maintain the buffer.

question: why was the Federal Tort Claims Act needed, I thought the Bill of Rights gave us the right to go to court against the US Government?
human_answer: The Bill of Rights does not expressly give anyone the right to go to court against the federal government. These first 10 Amendments to the Constitution guarantee basic civil rights and liberties like freedom of speech, press, and religion. The Federal Tort Claims Act prescribes a uniform procedure for handling of claims against the United States, for money damages only, on account of damage to or loss of property, or personal injury or death, caused by the negligent or wrongful act or omission of a Government employee while acting within the scope of his or her office or employment, under circumstances where the United States, if a private person, would be liable in accordance with the law of the place where the act or omission occurred.

If you try to skip ahead to a part of the video that hasn't loaded yet, your video has to stall to buffer that part.

When you click the progress bar, the video has to download additional data in order to make sure that the new section of the video is loading properly. This is why fully buffered YouTube videos will buffer again from where you click on the progress bar.

This is done to give users a more consistent viewing experience, and to save bandwidth, since most people don’t watch videos all the way through.  Additionally, if you try to skip ahead to a part of the video that hasn't loaded yet, your video stalls in order to buffer that part. This is because the video player has to "catch up" to the user's requested position by loading the missing data. 
 
 YouTube uses these ABR algorithms to attempt to give users a more consistent viewing experience while also saving bandwidth. Most people don't watch videos all the way through, so with 1 billion hours of video streamed every day, it would be a big waste of resources to buffer thousands of long videos for all users at all times. Therefore, the player will decide what quality the video can reasonably run without interruption.

question: How were continents, countries and coastlines mapped out prior to the invention of satellites?
human_answer: Early maps, especially coastal maps, were created using observations taking from ships, as naval navigations is more accurate compared to land navigation.  Before the mid 1700s, dead reckoning (DR) navigation was the primary method, which involved iteratively advancing your position away from your last known position, which suffered from inaccuracies.  Eventually, celestial navigation (using the stars) became commonplace.  Navigation is important to cartography, as in order to create a useful map, one first needs to know what they are observing/where they are observing from.  Map projections were also important; projections such as the mercator projection made it possible to represent a spherical world on a flat map, and were used to sail the seas by the early 1800s.

question: How does CRISPR work in a practical sense?
human_answer: CRISPR stands for “clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats.” The CRISPR/Cas9 tool was first described in 2012 and 2013, and scientists around the world soon started using it to alter an organism’s genome, the entire set of its DNA instructions.. Researchers have already used the tool to fix genetic diseases in animals, combat viruses, sterilize mosquitoes, and prepare pig organs for human transplants. They've even used it to precisely and efficiently edit the DNA of human cells. The good news is that today you can purchase your own CRISPR kit for as little as $130. The bad news is that you can only cut, copy, and paste existing genetic material, not create life from scratch.
